bibl.title: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Hugh S. Cumming, October 27, 1925

div1.p: Ravenel discusses the influences of Henry Rose Carter's extrinsic incubation theory and Finlay's mosquito theory on Reed's work.

div1.head: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to Hugh S. Cumming, October 27, 1925
div1.opener:
? Biographic
Ravenel, Mazyck
Be
C O P Y
UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI
Columbia
October 27, 1925.
Bacteriology and Preventive
Medicine
Dr. H.S. Cumming,
Surgeon General,
U. S. P. H. S.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear General Cumming:
div1.p:
Referring once more to the part played by Doctor
Carter's observation on the extrinsic period of incubation of yellow fever
on Doctor Reed's work, I have found some interesting material. Gorgas in
“Sanitation in Panama” quotes Reed as saying:- “We were also much impressed
by the valuable observations, ***during the year 1898 by Surgeon Henry R.
Carter. *** Other observations made by us since our arrival confirmed Carter's
conclusion, thus pointing, as it seemed to us, to the presence of an inter-
mediate host, such as the mosquito. *** In view of the foregoing observations
we concluded to test the theory of Finlay on human being.” Gorgas points out,
what we know to be true, that Reed and his Commission had worked along other
lines for a considerable time before changing to this plan. In another place
Reed says:- "To Dr. Carlos Finlay, of Havana, must be given, however, full
credit for the theory of the propagation of yellow fever by means of the
mosquito, which he proposed in a paper read before the Royal Academy in that
city at tis session on the 14th day of August, 1881.

Kelly, in his book on “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”,
quotes Reed as saying:- “That in view of the splendid work of Ross, Bignami,
and others with regard to the propagation of malarial fever, together with
the well-known thermal influences intimately connected not only with the
epidemiology of the disease in the United States, but also with its endemiology
on the Island of Cuba, it was the highest importance that the agency of an
-2-
intermediate host, such as the mosquito, should either be proven or disproven.”

I cannot understand how these quotations gibe with the letter of
Reed to Dr. Carter, a copy of which you were kind enough to give me. It is most
curious that Reed did not give credit to Carter in any of his publications as
having been the one who influenced him most in turning to the study of the
mosquito.

Since getting home, I have reread the article which I wrote for
the American Journal of Public Health on Doctor Carter, and I hope that when
it comes out you will show it to Miss Carter. In view of what I have quoted
to you, it is impossible for me to believe that Reed's letter was meant to be
taken literally. You will note also in that letter the very curious use of the
word “importance” in the last sentence.

In Gorgas' Book you will find it stated, and Reed stated the same
thing to me personally, that Reed discussed the matter with Dr. Finlay a good
deal before he commenced the mosquito work and was thoroughly familiar with
Dr. Finlay's ideas on the subject. In Reed's paper, “The Etiology of Yellow
Fever, Preliminary Note”, given at the Indianapolis meeting of the American
Public Health Public Health Association, he says:- “We here desire to express
our sincere thanks to Dr. Finlay who accorded us a most courteous interview
and has gladly placed at our disposal his several publications relating to
yellow fever, during the past nineteen years; and also for ova of the species
of mosquito with which he had made his several inoculations.” These statements
do not accord with Dr. Carter's recollections taken down by his daughter that
Reed said he did not want to know anything about the mosquito idea, as he wished
to proceed to the work with a mind free and unbiased. I must say that I can
hardly conceive of any scientific man going at a piece of work without a
-3-
thorough acquaintance with all that had been done before. Dr. Reed would have
been blind and deaf if he had not seen or heard of Dr. Finlay's theory and the
work he had done, but we do not have to reason about this matter for Reed says
himself that he consulted Dr. Finlay and got everything from him possible.

As I stated before, I am interested only in the historical side
of the matter, I had a tremendous admiration for Dr. Carter, had the honor of
his friendship for a good many years, have always stated that his work was an
outstanding piece of epidemiological investigation, and have always been con-
vinced that he was the brains behind Gorgas' success in Panama. You can see
then that I am not trying to detract from Dr. Carter's credit.
